text_array: Hello! My name is Skwarka and I want to thank you by checking out my project!!!

I'm not gonna spend much time talking about it here, but if you have any questions, comments or concerns, feel free to leave some feedback on the GitHub page here or you can message me via Discord, my user name is Skwarka#0047
Getting Started

If you're reading this it either means you told me you where new here or that you needed a refresher. What you are currently reading is this books 'on-load' room. As a player, all you need to know is that it is the room that loads on it's own once you open a new book. I'll tell you how to open new books later once you are ready to move on from this one.

Before we get too far I want to point out the 'Notes' tab in the top right corner. Hit the plus sign to open it and play around with it for a bit to get used to it. Through out basically every gamebook you are going to want to take notes, and while you could take them down with pen and paper, you can also type them up into the notes box. As long as you save the game the notes will stay with you. Even if you close the window you will be able to load them right back!
Once you are comfortable with the notes tab, click here!

What you've just done is effectively turning the page. When you clicked on that bit of text it passed a command directly to the console that told it to turn the page to this one.
That is the easiest way to navigate books as long as the person who wrote the book added in the correct commands.
The other way to turn pages is to type in the console.
Go ahead and try it now, type turn to 2.

What you've just done is effectively turning the page. When you clicked on that bit of text it passed a command directly to the console that told it to turn the page to this one.
That is the easiest way to navigate books as long as the person who wrote the book added in the correct commands.
The other way to turn pages is to type in the console.
Go ahead and try it now, type turn to 3.

Awesome, navigating this way is the default way to move through books. You keep using turn to [x] commands or you can use the shorter goto [x] command, they are functionally identical.
Some rooms are longer than others, and while I find the animation cool, there are times when you may want to skip it.
There are 2 ways to do this. You can either hold the ctrl key while you click on a `turn to [x]` command or you can add a `-false` flag onto the end of a goto command (i.e. `goto 3 -false`).

When you're ready

First, some important info. If you called for a room and it is taking to long to print, you can stop it using the command `stop`.
This will stop the print exactly where it is. You can also press `ctrl + C` to send a stop command.
Alternatively, if you call another `goto [x]` command it will start by issuing a stop and then executing the given command (this is true for almost any command by the way, a new one should always stop any ongoing ones).
When you're ready to move on goto 5, otherwise be ready to sit here for a while:

See what you did there was clicking, but you need to type turn to 2 if you want to get anywhere.
I admire your persistance, but you need to type turn to 2 if you want to get anywhere.

short_name: Example Room Object, does not need to be unique, just serves as a way to help keep the room human trackable
text_array: The text        to display as the player enters the room.
The text to display as the player gets ready to leave the room and lists where they can go. For instance, I'd recommend room
(#1).

What happens if you put a line-break in the middle
of a line? DOWNLOAD
